brief_metadata.target_audience: Marketing, HR, Finance, Sales professionals, Executives, Team Leads, Directors, Managers

module_overview.description: Create compelling visions and strategic clarity while developing customer empathy. Run the Foundations Sprint activity (Basics > Differentiation > Magic Lenses) to help teams focus on what matters most.
module_objectives: Communicate the importance of compelling visions and clarity of purpose
Develop customer empathy using various tools and techniques
Apply Foundations Sprint methodology to create strategic focus
module_overview.key_activity: Foundations Sprint - Basics, Differentiation, and Magic Lenses exercises

sections.section_title: Compelling Vision and Clarity of Purpose
learning_objectives: Communicate the importance of aligning organizations around a crisp, believable, compelling and inspiring vision
Experience methods for creating such visions and clear purposes
Articulate vision in ways that engage and motivate teams

key_points: Vision provides inspiration, engagement, commitment, and organizational cohesion (from learning outcomes)
High-performance teams need alignment around vision and purpose
Vision must be crisp, believable, compelling, and inspiring
Vision is different from mission, goals, or strategy

definitions.Vision: A clear picture of a desired future state that inspires and provides direction (source: learning outcomes)
definitions.Purpose: The reason an organization or team exists beyond making money - the 'why'
definitions.Alignment: State where all team members share understanding and commitment to common direction
definitions.Compelling: Powerful enough to overcome inertia and motivate action

concepts_to_explain: Why vision matters for business agility
Characteristics of effective visions (crisp, believable, compelling, inspiring)
Difference between vision, mission, purpose, strategy, and goals
Vision as guardrail for autonomous teams
The relationship between clarity and speed

needed: Examples of compelling visions from well-known companies
Marketing department vision example
HR transformation vision example
Finance function vision example
Before/after examples: vague vs compelling vision
Vision crafting exercise template
Bad vision examples and why they don't work
How to test if a vision is compelling

teaching_guidance.approach: Start with 'why vision matters', show examples good and bad, introduce characteristics, practice crafting
engagement_methods: Pair discussion: What's your current team/org vision?
Small group: Evaluate vision examples against criteria
Gallery walk of vision statements with peer feedback
common_misconceptions: Vision is just a marketing statement
Vision doesn't matter for day-to-day work
Vision is set by leadership and cascaded down
Vision should be realistic and achievable (it should inspire, not just be realistic)
visual_suggestions: Vision vs Mission vs Strategy diagram
Alignment visual - aligned vs misaligned teams

learning_objectives: Explain the values, principles, tools and techniques needed to develop empathy and improve customer awareness
Apply tools such as persona maps, customer journey maps, empathy maps, customer value propositions
Recognize that everyone between you and the customer is an internal customer

key_points: Value is subjective to each customer (from learning outcomes)
Customer empathy is vital capability grounded in customer focus
Internal customers are everyone between you and end customer
Customer value, stakeholder value, and business value must align ('we all win together')

definitions.Customer Empathy: Deep understanding of customer's context, needs, pains, and aspirations (source: learning outcomes)
definitions.Persona: Semi-fictional representation of ideal customer based on research
definitions.Customer Journey Map: Visual representation of customer's experience over time
definitions.Empathy Map: Tool to understand customer's thoughts, feelings, actions, and environment
definitions.Value Proposition: Promise of value to be delivered - reason customer should choose you
definitions.Internal Customer: Anyone in your organization who depends on your work to serve the end customer

concepts_to_explain: Why value is subjective and context-dependent
How to identify and empathize with customers
The customer empathy toolkit: personas, journey maps, empathy maps, value propositions
Value chain thinking - 'we all win together'

needed: Marketing: Customer persona for B2B buyer

Sales: Customer value proposition examples
Blank templates for each tool (persona, journey, empathy map, value prop)

from_learning_outcomes: Tools: persona maps, customer journey maps, empathy maps, customer value propositions, business model canvas
Linking customer value, stakeholder value, business value

teaching_guidance.approach: Introduce concept of empathy and value subjectivity, demonstrate each tool with example, practice with relevant scenarios
engagement_methods: Quick empathy map exercise for familiar customer
Pair work: Create simple persona for your customer
Group activity: Map journey for a business process
Discussion: Who are your internal customers?
common_misconceptions: Only customer-facing roles need customer empathy
Features = value (features enable value but aren't value itself)
We know what customers want without asking

learning_objectives: Envision the future state of business agility
Learn ways to look backwards from that future to craft a compelling path
Gain understanding of why and how to use this activity with teams

key_points: Backcasting: Starting with desired future and planning backward (from learning outcomes)
Identifies capabilities, skills, behaviors, practices needed
Helps craft compelling path from current to future state
Makes the journey feel achievable by breaking it down

definitions.Future State: Clear picture of what success looks like when business agility is achieved
definitions.Backcasting: Planning method that starts with defining desired future and works backward to identify steps to get there (source: learning outcomes)
definitions.Capability: Organizational ability to perform a particular kind of work
definitions.Roadmap: Strategic plan showing path from current to future state

concepts_to_explain: Why backcasting is powerful vs traditional forward planning
How to envision a compelling future state
Identifying capability gaps between current and future
Creating realistic path while maintaining inspiring vision
Making abstract future concrete and tangible
How to use with teams to build shared understanding

needed: Marketing: Future state of agile marketing capability
HR: Future state of people-centric organization
Finance: Future state of adaptive financial planning
Backcasting exercise template and instructions
Example future state descriptions
Capability mapping examples
Roadmap visualization examples
How to facilitate future state envisioning session
from_learning_outcomes: Look backwards from future to craft compelling path
Identify new capabilities, skills, behaviors, practices needed
Understanding why and how to use with teams

teaching_guidance.approach: Guided visualization exercise, then backcasting analysis, then capability identification
engagement_methods: Guided visualization: Your team in 2 years with business agility

Pair share: What's different in the future?
Small groups: Work backward to identify 3-5 key capabilities needed
Gallery walk: Review each group's roadmap
common_misconceptions: The future is too uncertain to envision
Vision should be created by leadership only
We need to plan every step before starting
visual_suggestions: Current state vs future state comparison
Example roadmap from current to future

research_needs: Backcasting methodology and best practices

sections.section_title: Activity: Foundations Sprint (Basics > Differentiation > Magic Lenses)
learning_objectives: Apply the Foundations Sprint methodology to identify basics, differentiators, and magic lenses
Prioritize what matters most for strategic focus
Create clarity on where to invest time and resources

key_points_from_video: Foundation Sprint: 10-hour process over 2 days to create founding hypothesis (video 11:42-12:25)
Core team clears calendar, highly scripted activities (video 12:05-12:25)
Work alone together - note and vote method (video 21:17-22:14)
Decider role - one person makes final calls (video 21:53)

key_questions: What problem are you solving for them?
How do they solve it today?
phase_1_basics.insight_from_video: Almost embarrassingly simple, but teams have different answers (video 15:25)

phase_2_differentiation.description: Heart of Foundation Sprint - create clear, radically differentiated promise (video 29:46-30:48)
phase_2_differentiation.why_critical: People want to ignore new things - need clear differentiation to break through (video 29:58)
classic_differentiators: Easy to use to hard to use
Focused to one size fits all
phase_2_differentiation.custom_differentiators: Write custom good-to-bad continuums specific to your context (video 32:08-32:48)
phase_2_differentiation.2x2_chart: Plot on two axes with you in top-right, competitors in 'Loserville' (L-shaped other quadrants) (video 31:02-34:46)
phase_2_differentiation.requirements: Must be able to deliver AND customers must care (video 34:13-34:19)
phase_2_differentiation.realistic_assessment: Don't need to be best on ALL differentiators - focus on 1-2 (video 43:49-44:22)

phase_3_magic_lenses.description: Evaluate different approaches through multiple lenses (video 54:54-56:27)
five_lenses: Customer lens: Easy to use vs perfect solution to problem
Pragmatic lens: Cheap and fast to market
Growth lens: Reach most customers, easy to adopt
Money lens: Long-term value, biggest audience
Differentiation lens: How well does it deliver on differentiation?
phase_3_magic_lenses.purpose: Choose best path when multiple approaches could work (video 53:14-53:27)

founding_hypothesis.template: If we solve [this problem] for [this customer] with [this approach], we think they're going to choose it over the competitors because of [differentiator 1] and [differentiator 2] (video 16:35-16:47)
founding_hypothesis.output: Clarity in one sentence to test (video 16:54)

mini_manifesto.example: Google's 'Fast is better than slow' used in meetings for decisions (video 50:03-50:38)

from_video.customer: Artisans who want to sell online but find tech and marketing hard

from_video.description: Simple AI agents for everyday tasks
from_video.differentiators: Mobile first, Works out of the box

activity_flow_60_minutes: Introduction to Foundation Sprint concept (5 min)
Phase 1: The Basics - work alone together (15 min)
facilitation_keys_from_video: Use 'work alone together' - silence, then vote, then decider (video 21:17-22:14)
Designate clear decider role (usually senior leader) (video 21:53)
Use sticky notes and voting dots
Emphasize basics are warm-up for differentiation
Differentiation is the heart - spend most time here
Don't force alignment on being best at everything
Mini manifesto emerges from the work, not created separately
supplies_needed: Foundation Sprint template (Miro board or physical)
enterprise_adaptations: Frame as 'strategic focus exercise' not 'startup sprint'
Competition might be other departments, status quo, or external
Differentiation can be internal (how HR differentiates) or external (how we position to market)
Magic lenses evaluate project approaches, not just product approaches
Founding hypothesis becomes project charter or initiative brief
common_misconceptions_from_video: This seems too basic/obvious (teams actually have different answers) (video 23:26-24:44)
2x2 diagrams are BS (when done right, they're North Star) (video 35:03-36:24)
Why not just build and learn? (slowing down makes you faster long-term) (video 0:40-1:01)
Need to be better on everything (focus on 1-2 radical differentiators) (video 43:49-44:22)
All problems can be solved with more planning (complex contexts need experimentation)
